(1994) | Misc = }} '''''Aladdin: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack''''' is the soundtrack for the [[Walt Disney Pictures]] film, [[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|''Aladdin'']], released on cassette and [[compact disc]] in November 1992. A remastered reissue with altered lyrics and new artwork was released in 2001. A special edition reissue featuring two previously released demos and new artwork was released in 2004. The music featured on the album earned composer [[Alan Menken]] an [[Academy Award]] and a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score]], as well as a nomination for the [[BAFTA Award for Best Film Music]]. Menken also shared an Academy Award, Golden Globe and [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year]] with [[Tim Rice]] for the song "[[A Whole New World]]". ==Track listing== {{tracklist | headline = Original release (1992) and remastered reissue (2001) | extra_column = Performer(s) | all_music = [[Alan Menken]] | lyrics_credits = yes | title1 = Arabian Nights | note1 = * | lyrics1 = [[Howard Ashman]] | extra1 = [[Bruce Adler]] | title2 = Legend of the Lamp | note2 = dialogue performed by [[Robin Williams]] | extra2 = (score) | title3 = One Jump Ahead | lyrics3 = [[Tim Rice]] | extra3 = [[Brad Kane]] | title4 = Street Urchins | extra4 = (score) | title5 = One Jump Ahead (Reprise) | lyrics5 = Rice | extra5 = Brad Kane | title6 = Friend Like Me | lyrics6 = Ashman | extra6 = [[Robin Williams]] | title7 = To Be Free | extra7 = (score) | title8 = Prince Ali | lyrics8 = Ashman | extra8 = Robin Williams | title9 = [[A Whole New World]] | lyrics9 = Rice | extra9 = Brad Kane & [[Lea Salonga]] | title10 = Jafar's Hour | extra10 = (score) | title11 = Prince Ali (Reprise) | lyrics11 = Rice | extra11 = [[Jonathan Freeman (actor)|Jonathan Freeman]] | title12 = The Ends of the Earth | extra12 = (score) | title13 = The Kiss | extra13 = (score) | title14 = On a Dark Night | extra14 = (score) | title15 = Jasmine Runs Away | extra15 = (score) | title16 = Marketplace | extra16 = (score) | title17 = The Cave of Wonders | extra17 = (score) | title18 = Aladdin's Word | note18 = includes cue from [[When You Wish upon a Star]] | extra18 = (score) | title19 = The Battle | extra19 = (Score) | title20 = Happy End in Agrabah | note20 = ** | extra20 = (Score) | title21 = A Whole New World (Aladdin's Theme) | lyrics21 = Rice | extra21 = [[Peabo Bryson]] & [[Regina Belle]] }} (*) Lyrics revised for later pressings and remastered reissue.
(**) Version included on the original cassette release (1992) contains several alternate cues. {{tracklist | extra_column = Performer(s) | headline = Special Edition (2004) | lyrics_credits = yes | title22 = Proud of Your Boy (Demo) | lyrics22 = [[Howard Ashman]] | extra22 = [[Alan Menken]] | title23 = High Adventure (Demo) | lyrics23 = Ashman | extra23 = Alan Menken & [[Howard Ashman]] }} ==Songs== ===Arabian Nights=== "Arabian Nights", performed by The Peddler ([[Bruce Adler]]), opens the film. Initially a longer composition, Howard Ashman and Alan Menken's 1990 score treatment incorporated several reprises allowing The Peddler to comment on plot developments. The original lyric ''"Where they cut off your ear/if they don't like your face"'' received complaints from the [[American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee]] (ADC) and other groups upon the film and soundtrack's initial release. A new lyric, ''"Where it's flat and immense/and the heat is intense"'', was recorded for subsequent soundtrack pressings and home video releases.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1202224,00.html|title=The 25 Most Controversial Movies Ever|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=2007-03-16}} The subsequent line, "''It's barbaric, but hey, it's home,''" was left intact. An alternate version of the song utilizing lyrics from the original demo was later featured in ''[[The Return of Jafar]]'', performed by [[Brian Hannan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aladdincentral.org/music/englishanroj.html|title=Arabian Nights lyrics from The Return of Jafar|publisher=[http://www.aladdincentral.org Aladdin Central]}} This version was also used as the main titles theme for the [[Aladdin (TV series)|''Aladdin'' television series]]. ''[[Aladdin and the King of Thieves]]'' features a reprise performed by Adler originally recorded for the first film. "Arabian Nights" pops up in the movie's underscore quite often, primarily used as a theme for Jafar. ===One Jump Ahead=== "One Jump Ahead" is sung by [[Aladdin (Disney character)|Aladdin]] ([[Brad Kane]]) while he escapes from the guards carrying a stolen loaf of bread, explaining that this is the life he lives, he has no choice but to steal, much as he does not wish to. It replaced "You Can Count On Me", a song that would be used to introduce Aladdin but was considered too pokey{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,312563,00.html |title=Unsettled Score |author=Daly, Steve |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=1992-12-04 |accessdate=2008-03-13}}. Tim Rice and Alan Menken's biggest inspiration for "One Jump Ahead" was another cut song, "Babkak, Omar, Aladdin, Kassim", that would feature Aladdin and three friends removed from the film. During the writing, Rice and Menken also came to a [[ballad]] in the same vein, used in a later scene as "One Jump Ahead (Reprise)".''Aladdin Platinum Edition'', Disc 2: ''Diamond in the Rough: The Making of Aladdin - The Music''. The reprise, titled, "One Jump Ahead (Reprise)", is also used in the score as the theme for Aladdin. A slow version of the song (the reprise, specifically) is heard in the underscore frequently as a theme for Aladdin. ===Friend Like Me=== "Friend Like Me" is sung by the [[Genie (Aladdin)|Genie]] ([[Robin Williams]]) while he shows off his powers to Aladdin in a [[Cab Calloway]]-like musical, telling him that he is a friend unlike any other. It was the first scene in ''Aladdin'' to have its animation finished, and features some differences in character design.[[Andreas Deja]], [[Will Finn]], [[Eric Goldberg (film director)|Eric Goldberg]] and [[Glen Keane]].''Aladdin'' [[audio commentary]] - ''The Animator's'' This song was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]]; it was Ashman's last nomination. During the movie's end credits, an instrumental reprise of the song is featured. [[Alvin and the Chipmunks]] covered "Friend Like Me" for their 1995 Disney-themed album ''[[When You Wish Upon a Chipmunk]]''. ===Prince Ali=== "Prince Ali" is another flamboyant number sung by the Genie ([[Robin Williams]]) as he introduces Agrabah to Aladdin's royal alter ego, Prince Ali Ababwa with a giant caravan. During the song, Robin Williams imitates a Thanksgiving Parade commentor ("Don't they look lovely, [[June Lockhart|June?]]"), [[Walter Brennan]], and [[Ethel Merman]]. The film version cut a conceived intro for the song and two extra verses in the middle.[[Ron Clements]], [[John Musker]], [[Amy Pell]].''Aladdin'' commentary track - ''The Filmmaker's'' ===A Whole New World=== {{main|A Whole New World}} ===Prince Ali (Reprise)=== A parody of "Prince Ali" sung by [[Jafar (Aladdin)|Jafar]] ([[Jonathan Freeman (actor)|Jonathan Freeman]]), while the villain uses his newly gained powers to reveal Ali is only a street rat, and sending him to the ends of the earth. The filmmakers liked Jonathan Freeman's singing, and wanted to give Jafar a song of his own, but they rejected Menken and Ashman's original composition for the scene ("Humiliate the Boy") and a new piece composed by Tim Rice ("Why Me"), as they were too long. Instead, they used a reprise of "Prince Ali." ==Cut Songs== Howard Ashman and Alan Menken composed several songs for an initial story treatment of Aladdin prior to beginning work on ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]''Hochman, Steve (1994). ''The Music Behind the Magic: The Musical Artistry of Alan Menken, Howard Ashman & Tim Rice''. Burbank: Walt Disney Records.Culhane, John (1992). ''Disney's Aladdin: The Making of an Animated Film'' (1st ed.). New York: Hyperion. ISBN 1-56282-757-X. This story treatment incorporated several plot elements from the original folk tale and additional characters that were eliminated during later story development. Three songs from this score - "Arabian Nights," "Friend Like Me" and "Prince Ali" - survive in the final film. Menken composed several additional songs for the subsequent story revisions following Ashman's 1991 death, prior to Tim Rice's involvement with the project. Work tape, demo and master recordings of cut songs have been released in several formats, notably on the 1994 ''[[The Music Behind the Magic]]'' box set, the 2004 special edition soundtrack and the 2004 DVD release of the film{{cite web|url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/549/549036p1.html|title=Aladdin: Ultimate DVD review|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2004-09-17|accessdate=2007-03-16}}. 1990 Original Score - music by [[Alan Menken]], lyrics by [[Howard Ashman]]. *'''Arabian Nights''' *'''Arabian Nights (Reprise #1)''' *'''Babkak, Omar, Aladdin, Kassim''' *'''Arabian Nights (Reprise #2)''' *'''Friend Like Me''' *'''Proud of Your Boy''' â A demo version performed by Menken was featured on the 2004 special edition soundtrack. A pop version recorded by [[Clay Aiken]] was included on the 2004 DVD release of the film. *'''How Quick They Forget''' *'''Arabian Nights (Reprise #3)''' *'''High Adventure''' â A demo version performed by Menken and Ashman was featured on the 2004 special edition soundtrack. *'''Arabian Nights (Reprise #4)''' Additional Menken/Ashman demos *'''Call Me a Princess''' â A cover version was recorded by actress/singer [[Kerry Butler]] and released on her first solo album, ''Faith, Trust & Pixie Dust'' in May 2008. *'''Humiliate the Boy''' Menken solo demos *'''Count On Me''' Menken/[[Tim Rice]] demos *'''My Time Has Come''' *'''Why Me''' ==The Score== Alan Menken's score for ''Aladdin'' follows the compositional method also used in ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' and ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]'', with specific cues and motifs derived from the songs' melodies. *'''Aladdin''''s theme echoes the melody of "One Jump Ahead." It prominently appears in the score cues "Street Urchins," "To Be Free" and "Aladdin's Word." *'''Jasmine''''s theme is soft and sweet, but also sad-sounding, because she feels trapped. It is introduced in her first scene at the palace. *The '''Sultan''''s Theme is a royal fanfare, though it sounds fairly goofy, because the Sultan is a silly king to begin with. *'''Jafar''''s Theme is dark, like he is, an instrumental of "Arabian Nights." *'''Genie''''s Theme is "To Be Free." It is surprisingly sweet for a comic character, to show that he truly means well and just wants freedom, similar to Jasmine. Although it is associated with Genie in the film, the tune was combined with Jasmine's theme and rewritten for [[Disney's Aladdin: A Musical Spectacular]] as "To Be Free," Jasmine's song. When Aladdin and Jasmine are together, it is usually accompanied by "A Whole New World." == Unreleased Songs/Score == # âArabian Nightsâ (Instrumental) [1:20] # Legend of the Lamp (without narration) [1:17] # Jafar Plots [0:31] # Aladdin on the Run [0:31] # âOne Jump Aheadâ (Instrumental) [2:22] # âOne Jump Ahead Repriseâ (Instrumental) [1:01] # Princess Jasmine / The Sultan Gives Away His Ring [3:22] # Aladdin and Jasmine/The Guards Arrive [3:55] # Jasmine Confronts Jafar / Jafar in Disguise [2:37] # The Cave of Wonders (Full Version) (About 1 minute and 28 seconds of music wasnât included on the commercial CD releases) [6:23] # Aladdin Unconscious / The Genie [1:27] # âFriend Like Meâ (Instrumental) [2:25] # Leaving the Cave of Wonders / The Sultan Upbraids Jafar / Iago's Idea [2:55] # Aladdinâs First Wish / Creating Prince Ali [2:02] # âPrince Aliâ (Instrumental) [2:49] # The Sultan's Magic Carpet Ride [0:55] # On the Balcony [4:05] # âA Whole New Worldâ (Full Version) [2:45] (The version heard in the film includes about 15 seconds of score before the song starts) # Aladdin Almost Drowns [1:58] # Jasmine Chooses a Suitor / Jafar Knows Aladdinâs Secret / Aladdinâs Dilemma [1:05] # âPrince Ali Repriseâ (Instrumental) [1:05] # Jafar as Sultan / Aladdin Returns...
